Award.AwardTitle: MRI: Acquisition of Confocal Raman Microscope for the Enhancement of Research and Education at Iona College
Award.AbstractNarration:
With this award from the Major Research Instrumentation Program (MRI) and support from the Chemistry Research Instrumentation Program, Iona College will acquire an inverted confocal Raman microscope. A microscope, which combines a Raman spectrometer with a confocal optical microscope, provides qualitative and quantitative vibrational information for structural and molecular analysis of materials at both the microscopic and bulk level. By scanning across a sample with high spatial resolution it provides analytical information on a wide range of samples, including biological matrices. The acquisition will provide training to undergraduate students in the use of this modern analytical tool. It will strengthen research opportunities for students in STEP and CSTEP (Collegiate STEP) programs funded by New York State that encourage underrepresented groups and outreach activities to high school teachers and students.

The acquistion is aimed at enhancing research and education at all levels, especially in areas such as (a) studying in-situ microdroplet crystallization; (b) designing nanoparticle intracellular probes and small-molecule delivery/detection devices and probing cellular uptake of the nanocomplexes in situ for synthesis of drug delivery vehicles; (c) elucidating fundamental biotoxicity mechanisms of type-2 alkenes via examination of intracellular tracking of various molecular indicators for prediction of the toxicity of environmental chemicals; and (d) characterizing copper nitrosyls compounds and mechanisms of nitrosylations and denitrosylations to develop denitrosylations and catalysis for environmental/biological applications.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Intellectual Merit: With the support of this NSF grant, we established an instrumentation assembly that combines a highly configurable droplet-based experimental platform with a high spatial-resolution confocal Raman microscope. The instrument awarded, and the research training made possible from the support of NSF, vastly enhanced the availability and depth of research activities by PIs and expanded the quality of research training of students at Iona College. A confocal Raman microscope, which combines a Raman spectrometer with a confocal optical microscope, provides qualitative and quantitative chemical information for structural and molecular determination at both the microscopic and bulk level, with high spatial resolution in three dimensions on a wide range of samples, including biological systems. The major research projects enabled include: (1) studies of crystallization within small droplets– the systematic knowledge acquired brought significant insights into the understanding of the control of crystallization processes, for applications in pharmaceuticals, functional material synthesis and biomineralization; (2) demonstrated the application of Raman microscopy to quantitatively visualize osmosis-driven water transport across a model biological membrane. The study of membrane water permeability can be used to foster a deeper understanding of the process of cell homeostasis, which is responsible for the maintenance of stable physiological conditions in the human body; (3) the characterization of a biomembrane in order to learn the impact of drugs and cholesterol at the molecular level, using specific Raman intensity ratios as probes of the molecular order of the lipid biomembranes; and (4) characterization of new copper nitrosyls compounds and their reaction mechanisms, for a deeper understanding of the chemistry of nitrogen oxides with precious metals, including rhodium, that may be relevant to the work of environmental and/or atmospheric chemists who study NOx pollutant remediation by metal catalyst systems. This award directly supported the growth in ongoing research for PIs and their research students in the chemistry department at Iona College, in the fields of surface science, biophysical chemistry, and mechanistic inorganic chemistry.

Broader Impacts: The research enabled by the proposed instrument allowed important contributions to fields such as biomimetic materials synthesis, chemistry of cell membrane and catalysis. The awarded instrument has a direct impact on PIs in their disciplinary scholarly activities and allowed the PIs to continue to provide training and professional development opportunties for 30 undergraduates (20 women) and 4 high school students (2 women), to obtain quality experiences.  In addition to research training, all undergraduate researchers participate in conferences every year, including at the National Conference on Undergraduate Research (NCUR) and ACS National Meeting. Undergraduate research involvement has played a role in the success of these students, since the research students were able to largely attain a high GPA, stay retained in a science major, and, especially, develop an aptitude for advanced independent study. The commitment of the PIs to workforce development has created a perfect opportunity to help elevate these students to be better situated to immediately enter the national workforce in an effective fashion. The students involved in NSF funded research, by and large are not merely assisting in the achievement of the scientific goals of the project, but are broadening their skill set to have both general and specific applicability to the workforce: time management; mental discipline; attention to detail; follow-through; and of course knowledge of laboratory chemistry techniques, safety, and the scientific method. NSF-MRI enabled continued research opportunities for students in STEP and CSTEP (Collegiate STEP), programs funded by NY State that encourage underrepresented minorities to succeed in STEM. The PIs are also actively involved in outreach to the community through several invited presentations that reach a broad audience: science outreach seminars for Salesian High School (regular seminar series where science faculty from Iona College discuss their work with high school students and science teachers). In addition, the PIs' established an annual science symposium for the local high school community in order to inform and inspire future scientists by fostering young peoples' enthusiasm for science. This instrument superbly enhanced Iona's vision of integrating undergraduate research scholarship with education by exposing our students to high-quality research and education that enables them to increase their reasoning and critical thinking skills, making a significant impact upon their future careers in science.
